newsitem.title: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC: Strike hits Dominican Republic business, transport.
newsitem.headline: Strike hits Dominican Republic business, transport.

text.p: Businesses were closed and transportation snarled in parts of the Dominican capital and at least three southern areas on Tuesday after unions and other groups called a 24-hour general strike.

The strikers, including members of the collective Popular Organisations, the Central Union of Workers and two transportation workers unions, called the strike to demand a lower cost of living and creation of more jobs.
"We are going on strike because we have no other choice," Fernandez Pena, a member of Popular Organisations, said.

Police reported clashes in Santo Domingo on Tuesday when strikers, some of them wearing hoods, set tires on fire and attacked passing vehicles. Squadrons of police officers were sent to areas affected by the strike and Police Chief Miguel Sanz Jiminian guaranteed that order would be maintained and businesses protected.
President Leonel Fernandez told a televised news conference that the strikes were "remnants of the left" out of touch with political solutions in Latin America.
Last week, separate strikes by protesting workers in the Dominican Republic turned violent leaving one person dead and three wounded.
